title: BESSY
text:
The Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung <a href="GmbH">m. b. H.</a> ("English": Berlin <a href="Electron">Electron</a> <a href="Storage%20ring">Storage Ring</a> Society for <a href="Synchrotron%20Radiation">Synchrotron Radiation</a>), abbreviated "BESSY", is a research establishment in the <a href="Adlershof">Adlershof</a> district of <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>. Founded on 5 March 1979, it currently operates one of Germany's 3rd generation <a href="synchrotron">synchrotron radiation facilities</a>, BESSY II. Originally part of the <a href="Leibniz%20Association">Leibniz Association</a>, BESSY now belongs to the <a href="Helmholtz-Zentrum%20Berlin">Helmholtz-Zentrum Berlin</a> (since 1 January 2009).
Owing to the <a href="radiometry">radiometry</a> lab of the PTB <a href="http%3A//www.bessy.de/%3Fidart%3D86%26amp%3Bchangelang%3D5"></a>, BESSY is the European calibration standard for <a href="electromagnetic%20radiation">electromagnetic radiation</a>.
BESSY supplies synchrotron light and provides support for science and industry. There are institutional long-time users, like the <a href="Max-Planck-Gesellschaft">Max-Planck-Society</a>, the <a href="Bundesanstalt%20f%C3%BCr%20Materialforschung%20und%20-pr%C3%BCfung">German Federal Institute for Materials Research and Testing</a> (BAM) and the national <a href="metrology">metrology</a> institute of Germany (the <a href="Physikalisch-Technische%20Bundesanstalt">PTB</a>). Furthermore, research groups from other institutes or universities can apply for utilization (so called "beam time") for certain projects.
BESSY I.
This original synchrotron facility, costing the equivalent of 66.5 million <a href="Euro">Euro</a>, became operational on 19 December 1981. It was situated in <a href="Wilmersdorf">Wilmersdorf</a>, then a <a href="Boroughs%20and%20localities%20of%20Berlin">borough of Berlin</a>. The storage ring had a circumference of approx. 60 m. The circulating electrons that provided the radiation were in the energy range of 200 to 800 <a href="Electron%20volt">MeV</a> (<a href="Vacuum%20UV">Vacuum Ultraviolet</a> through <a href="Extreme%20ultraviolet">Extreme Ultraviolet</a>).
After its decommissioning in 1999, the component parts of the BESSY I machine were donated to the <a href="Synchrotron-Light%20for%20Experimental%20Science%20and%20Applications%20in%20the%20Middle%20East">SESAME project</a> by the German Authorities and have consequently been shipped to <a href="Jordan">Jordan</a>.
Famous achievements of BESSY I were the <a href="calibration">calibration</a> of the <a href="spectrometers">spectrometers</a> for the solar observatory probe <a href="Solar%20and%20Heliospheric%20Observatory">SOHO</a> as well as for the detectors for the <a href="Chandra%20X-ray%20Observatory">Chandra X-ray Observatory</a>.
BESSY II.
Groundbreaking for the new improved BESSY II synchrotron source in Adlershof took place on 4 July 1994, and the facility was inaugurated on 4 September 1998. The project cost was an equivalent of approximately 100 million Euros. The successor of BESSY I has a circumference of 240 m, providing 46 <a href="beam%20line">beam line</a>s, and offers a multi-faceted mixture of experimental opportunities (<a href="undulator">undulator</a>, <a href="Wiggler%20%28synchrotron%29">wiggler</a> and <a href="dipole%20magnet">dipole</a> sources) with excellent energy resolution. The combination of <a href="brightness">brightness</a> and time resolution enables both <a href="femtosecond">femtosecond</a> time and <a href="picometer">picometer</a> spatial resolutions.
Electrons can be accelerated to an energy of up to 1.7 <a href="Electron%20Volt">GeV</a> (<a href="X-rays">X-ray regime</a>), and are subsequently injected into the storage ring. Synchrotron radiation emerges from the dipole magnets that bend the beam on a circular path, as well as from undulators and wigglers. The total <a href="Power%20%28physics%29">power</a> input during regular operation is 2.7 <a href="Watt">MW</a>.
BESSY II can be run in different modes, according to the time-distance between the electron <a href="wave%20packet">wave packet</a>s that circulate in the storage ring:
Experiments at BESSY II are in the fields of <a href="X-ray%20absorption%20spectroscopy">X-ray absorption spectroscopy</a>, <a href="Photoemission%20spectroscopy">Photoemission spectroscopy</a>, <a href="Photoemission%20electron%20microscopy">Photoemission electron microscopy</a>, <a href="X-ray%20microscope">X-ray microscopy</a>, <a href="Infrared%20spectroscopy">Infrared spectroscopy</a>, <a href="laser%20cutting">femtosecond slicing</a>, <a href="X-ray%20lithography">X-ray lithography</a>, and <a href="X-ray%20crystallography">protein structure analysis</a>.
BESSY maintains a close co-operation with other synchrotron sources in the world, most notably with <a href="DESY">DESY</a> in <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>.
